case_vignette: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician with a 4-week history of fatigue, crampy abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and pain in his mouth and gums. He returned from a 2-week trip to the Dominican Republic 2 months ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Examination shows three 1.5-cm, painful ulcers in the mouth. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 75 fL, and leukocyte count is 11,900 mm3. Colonoscopy shows a cobblestone mucosa. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling really fatigued, having crampy abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and pain in my mouth and gums for the past 4 weeks.
Have you recently taken any new medications?
No, I haven't started any new medications.

Do you have a history of inflammatory bowel disease?

**Final Diagnosis:** Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - Considering symptoms and absence of recent medication use.

The presence of oral symptoms could suggest an association with Crohn's disease, but it's not definitive. Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis typically present with different symptoms, and Behcet disease usually involves oral ulcers and genital ulcers, along with other systemic symptoms.
